text: my name is Timothy Sullivan when I went
to Japan for the first time I was
getting an award and I was part of a
Shinto ceremony at a shrine in kyoto and
that was the first time I really saw
men's kimono up close and I thought it
was absolutely beautiful the word kimono
actually means thing to wear so for
hundreds of years it was standard daily
dress for everyone in Japan when I got
back I started wanting to learn a little
bit more about that and then I got an
email from one of the kimono retailers
in Japan who said that there's a kimono
teacher that is moving to New York and I
just thought hey Dad be interesting that
might be fun and I could really learn
how to put this thing on correctly
because if I go back to the ceremony
next year it would be wonderful if I
could wear men's kimono and wear it
properly and learn their ways not just
slap it on like a Halloween costume and
this is a shot of the toffee socks which
are the split toe socks and they are
quite old school this is the under
kimono and you tie the juban to secure
it in place now the next step is to put
on the kimono itself
you should pull it up over your
shoulders and put your arms through and
then of course adjust your collar that
is one of the very important things that
just enough of the under kemono the
juban is showing and that it lays at the
right area and we're securing the kimono
closed with a cloth and that just is the
basic closure teacher is adjusting the
collar and making sure that just the
right amount of the under collar is
exposed and that's one of the reasons
that there are such things as kemono
teachers because there's a lot of set
rules about how things should be worn
and you don't want to make any etiquette
mistakes so I mean we don't have classes
and you know how to put on your business
suit it's pretty obvious you know once
you learn how to tie a tie in the
Western world you can just wear it we're
getting to the meat and potatoes of it
this is tying the OB which is the B belt
here o sensei is really tugging very
tightly and keeping things taught and
tight is very important the proportions
are very important the width of the bow
compared to the center ty has to be as
you know specific balance
once you get into it it actually feels
really secure because you're basically
wearing an open piece of clothing so you
want it to be closed securely and once
the belt is on it feels very secure and
actually very comfortable and hero
sensei is monitoring very closely the
main belt I supposed to dip down in the
front if you're have a totally flat
stomach it's not very conducive to
having it dipped down so if you have a
small little belly it it sits perfectly
and they actually sell a padded belly
that you can velcro around your waist
for men I have just enough pop belly to
make it good
and this is called the hottie which is
basically like the jacket it goes over
the kimono it's the same color same
fabric and it has the family crest those
white circles are the family crest and
now I'm tying the holiday hemo which is
the string closure for the jacket and
then a fan which is the one of the
required accessories
sitting back on your legs like that is
called sitting SE za i can do it for
about five minutes i want to be able to
sit say it's off style or for as long as
i can so i'll do some training before i
go
